rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Hypericum perforatum
rdf:Description.ns4:abstract: Hypericum perforatum, known as St. John's wort, is a flowering plant in the family Hypericaceae and the type species of the genus Hypericum. Possibly a hybrid between H. maculatum and H. attenuatum, the species can be found across temperate areas of Eurasia and has been introduced as an invasive weed to much of North and South America, as well as South Africa and Australia. While the species is harmful to livestock and can interfere with prescription drugs, it has been used in folk medicine over centuries, and remains commercially cultivated in the 21st century. Hyperforin, a phytochemical constituent of the species, is under basic research for possible therapeutic properties.
rdf:Description.ns1:ecology:
H. perforatum is native to temperate parts of Europe and Asia, but has spread to temperate regions worldwide as an invasive weed.
H. perforatum temperate invasive
rdf:Description.ns1:taxonomy:
1913 botanical illustration of H. perforatum by Jost Fitschen in Pflanzen der Heimat 1913 botanical illustration of H. perforatum by Jost Fitschen in Pflanzen der Heimat botanical illustration H. perforatum Jost Fitschen Pflanzen der Heimat Pflanzen der Heimat Hypericum perforatum was selected to be the type species around which the genus Hypericum is based because of its wide cosmopolitan distribution ; it is the most common species of the genus in many of the areas it is found, and is one of the most widely known plants among the St John's worts in folklore and medicine.
The current accepted placement of H. perforatum within its genus can be summarized as follows:
Hypericum perforatum type species Hypericum cosmopolitan distribution
H. perforatum
